Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: The grandmother learns that a family member is dealing with a significant personal crisis.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A bride-to-be and her entourage arrive early, visibly anxious about the tight wedding schedule.
Story: The phone buzzed in my pocket just as I was sweeping up the last of the morning’s hair clippings. It was my daughter, her name lighting up the screen, and I knew it wasn’t just a casual call. My mind raced—she’d mentioned her husband hadn’t been himself lately, and I’d promised to be there for her, to check in, to be the steady presence our family needed. But before I could answer, the bell above the salon door jingled. The bride-to-be and her bridesmaids swept in, faces tight with nerves, glancing at their watches. I was supposed to greet them warmly, put them at ease, make this day special. My hand hovered over my phone, heart pounding. I could hear my daughter’s voice in my head, needing comfort, and at the same time, I saw the anxious eyes of the bridal party, expecting my full attention. The weight of both worlds pressed down on me, and for a moment, I stood frozen, torn between the family who needed me and the clients who depended on me to make their day perfect.
